conclusion: Car A enters from the lower-right, travelling roughly toward the upper-left.
Blocks in the car’s corridor, in order of distance, are the red row, then the green row. Blue, yellow, and orange piles are farther away or off-line.
Blue, yellow, and orange piles will not be hit unless A is deflected a large additional angle.
The nose of A reaches the red row first.
The hit is close to head-on, so most of A’s forward momentum is transferred straight into the red cubes.
Red cubes scatter slightly forward and sideways; A loses a large part of its speed and its front corner rides up a little on the block, turning the car’s heading a few degrees to the left.
Because of the small leftward deflection, A’s new path intersects the nearer (right-hand) green cube.
Impact speed is already reduced; the hit pushes the first green cube into the next two, but there is not enough energy to topple the whole line or to spin the car much further.
Almost all of A’s kinetic energy has now gone into the two collisions.
Rolling resistance on the cloth quickly removes the little energy that is left.
The car comes to rest within a few centimetres of the green row, between the scattered red pieces behind it and the still-standing blue/yellow/orange structures farther away.
Orange blocks are well to the left of the deflected path – no collision.
Blue and yellow stacks are farther up-field – the car stops short of them.
A will first collide with the red row of blocks, then (after a slight leftward deflection) with the front cube of the green row, and will finally stop just in front of the green row.
